section.title: Probability Rules

statement.p: Probability is the measure of the likelihood of a random phenomenon or chance behavior occurring.
It deals with experiments that yield random short-term results or outcomes yet reveal long-term predictability.
The long-term proportion in which a certain outcome is observed is the probability of that outcome.
As the number of repetitions of a probability experiment increases, the proportion of times that a certain outcome is observed gets closer to the probability of the outcome.

exploration.title: Simulating Coin Flips on the TI-84 Plus Calculator
exploration.p: Probability is closely related to performing experiments. However, it is often tedious and time-consuming to perform an experiment by hand. For example, it would be tedious to roll a pair of dice 1000 times and record all the data, but if we program a computer to simulate the experiment we can often get results in a fraction of the time it would take to do the experiment the old fashioned way. Another side benefit of computer simulation is that you can easily share the computer code with others, so they can simulate your experiment as well, and perhaps even improve it.
The following program written in TI-84 BASIC will simulate the flipping of a coin to demonstrate the Law of Large Numbers.

figure.caption: TI-84 BASIC code for simulating coin flips.

exploration.p:
When run (executed), the program does the following:
Clears lists 1, 2 and 3.
Prompts you for a number, N, which is the number of coin flips to perform.
Generates N, 0's or 1's (pseudo-randomly) and saves the results in list 1. (0=tails, 1=heads)
Initialize an accumulator variable, A, to 0. A will keep track of the total number of heads.
Set I=1 (I for index) then for each coin flip:
Add the coin value to A,
Store the value of I into list 2,
Store the current proportion of heads, A/I into list 3.
Increment I by 1. Exit the loop if I > N, otherwise repeat the loop.

After running the COINFLIP program, you can examine the output it generated by viewing the data in lists 1, 2 and 3. The ideal way to examine the data however is to create a scatter plot using lists 2 and 3. The following STAT PLOT screen shows you how to plot the output of the COINFLIP program.

exploration.p: Finally by pressing zoom and then choosing 9:ZoomStat you can generate a plot similar to the two scatter plots below, each of which represents N=50 coin flips. The x-axis of the scatter plot is the coin flip number, while the y-axis is the proportion of flips which are heads. Notice that as the number of flips increases the proportion of heads generally gets closer to 0.5 or 50%. This is precisely what the Law of Large Numbers implies.

section.p: Before the advent of computers, probability was typically studied in a different way which we will label the Classical Approach, as opposed to the experimental or Empirical Approach to the study of probability. We will need some new vocabulary in order to discuss the classical approach.

statement.p: The sample space, S, of a probability experiment is the collection, or set of all possible outcomes.

An event is any collection of outcomes from a probability experiment. Thus an event is a subset of a sample space. It is common to denote events with capital letters such as E, F, G, E_1, E_1, \ldots, E_n .

aside.title: Spaces in Mathematics
aside.p: It is common in mathematics to use the word space to mean set. The reason for using a different word is because, sets have no structure, whereas a space is a set equipped with some additional structure.

statement.p: Two events E and F are independent if the occurrence of event E in a probability experiment does not affect the probability of event F. Two events are dependent if the occurrence of event E in a probability experiment affects the probability of event F.
Determine if the following pairs of events are independent or dependent.
You are late for work. Your car runs out of gas.
Winning a game of Monopoly. Winning the lottery
You gain weight. You eat fast food for dinner every night.
Speeding on the interstate highway. Getting pulled over by a police officer.
Owning a dog. Growing an herb garden.
Robbing a bank. Going to jail.

remark.p: Knowing two events are disjoint means that the events are dependent. Why? Consider the example of pulling chips numbered 0-9 out of a bag. Suppose event E corresponds with pulling a chip labelled with a 1 or a 2 out of the bag, E=\{1,2\} and suppose F=\{3,4\}, F corresponds with pulling a 3 or 4 chip out of the bag. Notice that these events are disjoint because they have no outcomes in common. Finally, notice that if we know that event E occurred (a 1 or 2 is drawn), then we know for certain that F (drawing a 3 or 4) did not occur. Thus the occurrence of E affects the probability of event F and vice versa.

example.title: Flipping Two Heads in a Row

statement.p: What is the probability that you flip a fair coin twice and get heads twice?

solution.p:
Since these events are independent we can use the multiplication rule:
P(H \text{ and } H) \amp = P(H) \cdot P(H)
\amp = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}
\amp = \frac{1}{4} = 0.25 = 25 \%

example.title: Rolling Four Ones in a Row

statement.p: What is the probability that you roll 4 ones in a row when you roll a fair, six sided die four times?

solution.p:
Since these events are independent we can use the multiplication rule:
P(1 \text{ and } 1 \text{ and } 1 \text{ and } 1) \amp = P(1) \cdot P(1) \cdot P(1) \cdot P(1)
\amp = \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{1}{6}
\amp = \frac{1}{1296} \approx 0.000716 = .0716 \%

statement.p: What is the probability of selecting a two or a club from a deck of cards?

solution.p:
These events are not disjoint, because there is one card that is both a 2 and a club, thus we must use the general addition rule.
P(2 \text{ or club} ) \amp = P(2) + P(\text{club}) - P(2\cap \text{club})
\amp = \frac{4}{52} + \frac{13}{52} - \frac{1}{52}
\amp = \frac{16}{52} = \frac{4}{13} \approx 31\%

section.title: Conditional Probability and the General Multiplication Rule

statement.p: The notation P(F|E) is read the probability of event F given event E. It is the probability that event F occurs, given that event E occurred.

fact.title: General Multiplication Rule
fact.p: Notice that the general multiplication rule follows from the conditional probability rule.

Two events E and F are independent if P(E|F) = P(E) or, equivalently, if P(F|E) = P(F). This is the same thing as saying that knowing that one event occurred does not affect the probability of the other event occurring (this is the definition of independence from ).

statement.p: Suppose a student guesses every answer on a multiple choice quiz. There are four questions and each question has four choices: A, B, C or D.

solution.p: Multiple choice questions are independent because the answer you give on one does not affect your probability of getting any other question correct.

How many ways can different students from a class of 10 be assigned to work the first three homework problems on the board? Does order matter?

solution.p:
Order does matter, so we must compute the number of permutations.
10 P 3 = \frac{10!}{(10-3)!} = \frac{10!}{7!} = \frac{10\cdot 9\cdot 8\cdot 7!}{7!} = 10\cdot 9\cdot 8 = 720

statement.p: How many ways can a focus group of 5 consumers be selected from a list of 25 people who purchased a particular product? Notice that order doesn’t matter since we are just forming a focus group, so changing the order in which people are selected does not change the group.

A group of four friends (Alan, Becky, Curtis and Dylan) is going to play volleyball by dividing up into two teams. How many different combinations of the 4 friends taken 2 at a time are there? List all the combinations.

solution.p:
Notice that order does not matter, and further notice that by picking one team, the other team is also determined.
4 C 2 = \frac{4!}{(4-2)!\,2!} = \frac{4!}{2!\,2!} = \frac{4\cdot 3\cdot 2!}{2!\,2!} = 6

However, the last three pairings are repeats of the first three, so there are exactly 3 possible team pairs. Because choosing a team of two also forces the pairing of the other team, we get exactly half of 4C2.
